So we've done this one before, just wanted to check in to see if there 
was any new state-of-the-art thinking about this.

Assume:  I have an object model / relational database model (one, the 
other, and / or a mapping between them) that describes the domain 
objects of interest to me.  I would like to expose this in a naive 
fashion to via a RESTful interface;  i.e., assuming something like

GET /Entity --> a representation of the extent (all instances of class 
/ rows in associated table)
GET /Entity?id=xxx --> a represenation of the particular instance of 
Entity with id=xxx
POST /Entity <-- some representation of an Entity --> creates new 
/Table?id=yyy, redirects to it

It would be nice to have:

(1) a declarative way to describe the ER table.  There are many of 
these that generate DDL and object stubs or code
(2) a declarative way to map the ER model to a resource model / URI 
namespace
(3) a runtime framework which glues the two together
(4) preferably Python, but patterns / research in this area of any type 
is good
(5) abstraction of view / controller and app workflow to generate UI 
from declarative description a plus

Waterken looks interesting, but the capability stuff is 
overcomplicating unless it solves a specific problem you've got.

Kuhlman's FSM stuff is close, but no cookie:  modeling workflows, not 
an ER or object model.

Anyone one else?

jb
